Lost in Automation: My 1200+ Hour Obsession with Satisfactory

Ready to build stuff? If you're like me, Satisfactory will take over your brain, both in the game and outside. I've spent countless hours not just playing but also dreaming about conveyor belts, figuring out logistics, and even messing around with tools like Satisfactory Calculator and Satisfactory Modeler. Fair warning: this game is addictive as hell.

Map: The world of Massage is like its own character. It‚Äôs massive, super pretty, and packed with different biomes, crazy creatures (watch out for those creepy spider things!), and hidden secrets just waiting to be found. Exploring is a fun adventure and adds even more to an already deep game.

Progression: Satisfactory does a great job of gradually making things trickier. As you unlock new tiers, you get to build cooler stuff and expand your base. Jumping to nuclear power can seem intimidating at first, but using blueprints and external tools makes it way easier to handle the tough parts. These player-made tools are super helpful for designing factories and figuring out what machines you need for specific outputs.

Endgame: Completing everything 100% isn‚Äôt as hard as it sounds if you stay dedicated. My only real letdown was how the story wrapped up ‚Äî it felt kinda weak after all the time I put in. That said, the new content added in update 1.1 totally keeps things interesting and fresh, so I‚Äôm still hooked.

Satisfactory, a factory-building video game developed by Coffee Stain Studios, was officially released on September 10, 2024, on Steam. From my 300-hour experience playing Satisfactory, I am confident that this game should be rated 3.5 out of four stars.
	Satisfactory takes place in a technologically advanced future where the player starts out in a small rocket, landing on an uncharted planet. While on the rocket, a display screen shows the mission: to build a factory for FICSIT Corporation. Upon landing, the player notices that it looks similar to Earth, with grass and trees. The player will also discover that there are hostile alien creatures. To help navigate the environment, an AI voice, called A.D.A., talks to the player, giving instructions. Scattered across the planet are ore deposits that the player must extract resources from. Using these resources, the player will build multiple machines to refine materials as well as produce electricity. As the factory grows increasingly complex, the player is able to create an ever-expanding factory. Essentially, the player is there to create an automated process of manufacturing materials using a network of machines and conveyor belts, where the final products are sent up through a space elevator to FICSIT corporation.
	Satisfactory will not be entertaining for everyone, but those who have the mind of an engineer will be deeply engaged with its gameplay. At first, the game is effective at keeping your attention. There are milestones and phases that can be completed as a way of progression, and completing milestones unlocks new machines and tools. This creates a consistent feeling of advancement through the progression line for you. There are also many areas to explore throughout the alien world, providing the feeling of adventure. Additionally, Satisfactory has multiplayer support to create a more enhanced experience through collaboration and teamwork with other players. However, once you complete all the milestones there is no definite end goal anymore, which can cause a loss of interest. Also, the exploration of the game is usually overly repetitive and tedious.
	Satisfactory has a mysterious storyline to it that is optional to explore. Because the main goal is to construct a factory, this secondary storyline is mostly in the background. The game was mainly designed to be geared toward building a factory with efficiency, resource management, and optimization, but there is an adventurous aspect to the game. There is an incentive to explore to collect items, and sometimes there are mysterious objects that add to the story while also adding to industrial design and optimization. This storyline brings up profound questions. Because the player of the game builds a factory for a mysterious corporation, and the player is also considered their property it raises the questions towards the player: what are the motives of FICSIT, and why am I considered their property? Some strange objects can be found called Somersloops and Mercer Spheres. These strange objects cause A.D.A. to malfunction and say strange messages that come from an alien entity. This story relates to reality in a way, as sometimes we do not know the meaning of the work we do within our lives. Just like the player of the game sometimes we blindly follow our passions or routines without asking the question: is this truly meaningful?
	Overall, Satisfactory is a highly exceptional video game. It is a very thought-provoking game, intentionally designed and geared towards engineering and automation. Its great progression design keeps you engaged in the experience, but its exploration is more mundane. Additionally, Satisfactory‚Äôs background story raises many questions about the true meaning of the player‚Äôs identity within the game. For these reasons, I give Satisfactory a 3.5 out of four stars and recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a challenge through industrial design.

The real problem started when the game followed me offline. I walk through supermarkets mumbling about inefficient layouts. I look at escalators and genuinely consider their throughput rate. I rearranged my kitchen because my ‚Äúproduction lines‚Äù weren‚Äôt optimized for sandwich assembly. Even my dreams lag because I keep trying to feed my subconscious through a Mk.3 belt.

Satisfactory isn‚Äôt just a game it‚Äôs a lifestyle simulator for people who think spreadsheets are a form of emotional comfort. If you‚Äôve ever wanted to lose touch with reality while achieving machine-like perfection, welcome home. Just remember: the factory must grow, and your social life must wait.

I obtained this game at the recommendation of a gaming buddy, he swore and promised it was an amazing game.

After playing it for a bit, I have to say I can't agree with that assessment - but let me be specific of what I mean when I say that.

Don't get me wrong - this game is graphically well-put-together and feels polished. It has a decent amount of content in it.

My problem however is with the purpose you have in the game and the lack of variety of things to do.

Ultimately, all you are doing in this game is just making factories for the sake of making bigger and better factories. That's it. Exploration? It's just for finding new rare resources or for new sites to build more factories. Survival? It's just for making more factories. Factories are all that matter in this game ultimately.

But what is a factory except just a means to an end - an end that doesn't even exist in this game?

I've had people try to hype me up for the game talking about: "Oooh, but there's a space elevator!" Cool, can you personally take that space elevator to space and build your own space station with a shipyard, and then build a fleet of warships out of separate customizeable parts/blocks/etc, and then take that fleet to go conquer another solar system and/or planets? No? Then what's the point of the space elevator? It's not really a space elevator at all! It's just another factory component disguised as a "space elevator".

There are no starships you can build, no solar systems to conquer, not even FPS combat with aliens - It's just endless factory-grinding, resource-processing, and conveyor belt spam. Given you can't actually do anything meaningful with your factory except make a bigger factory, what's even the point of it? It's just a gigantic waste of time.

When I play a game, I want to feel like there's an actual greater purpose and massive goals to accomplish and hurdles to overcome and villains to defeat, rather than just endless grinding for the sake of endless grinding. If I'm going to grind with factory work in the game, it better be for the end goal of building something amazing that can do amazing things to complete an amazing goal - and by "amazing", I mean something other than just being another piece of factory equipment.

Why can't I build starships and go explore the galaxy? I don't want to sit around doing endless factory spam. I want to build tanks, ships and space cruisers and then go crush the local wildlife and conquer alien civilizations with what my factories have made. I want to build automatic rifles with high-capacity magazines and render certain undesireable local alien wildlife extinct. I even want to explore strange new worlds and colonize them with such notoriety that it makes the Klendathu Drop from Starship Troopers look like a toddler's birthday party and so I get a holiday made in my name, and centuries later that holiday gets virulently hated by some blue-haired nutcase college-age space-kids with nose rings and daddy-issues.

But nope, you can't do any of that in this game. It's just more and more factory nonsense.

Suffice to say, this game is definitely not for me.

I have studied Lean and SixSigma and have more than a decade of experience in assembly line based manufacturing processes and optimization. I find great joy in creating well designed, automated, optimized manufacturing lines. So this game was made for me and it does starts very strong. Super fun for the first 30 hours, colorful, well described tasks, quirky humor. Unfortunately it falls into the usual trap of the survival/crafting genre. You start like collect some wood to power your iron mine and forge to make some iron rods. Easy enough. 50 hours in and you make something like a pseudodimensional crystaline resonator matter vessel using similar non-sense base materials. The grounded early game goes out of the window. Annoying.
 
My main gripe is that around and over phase 3, the game drops the fun and turns into pure time sink. Grind for the sake of grind. Make 1000 of an item that takes 2 mins per. That alone takes 33 hours game time. Sure you can bump up the speed but it has such ridiculous base material and energy needs that your smelters can't keep up. Also, while your mines can upgrade, your factories can't. You need to build more and more of those to handle the mine. Vertical building is encouraged, but managing the conveyors and the spliters/mergers on vertical builds is a major pain. At one point, you say F. it and accept the fact the stuff will just hang in the air and clip like hell. This will trigger everyone with the type of OCD that actually made you play the game the first place. Turns the initially fun gameplay into a frustrating endgame grind.  

Also, you really don't need any of the transports. conveyors work perfectly fine. You don't transport raw materials on anything other than conveyors. You move the end items over longer distance. For that, even your inventory is good enough. Tubes, grid switches, useless. If you create a robust electric grid, there will be power to run everything all the time and zipline and jetpack around.

Why can't I build starships and go explore the galaxy? I don't want to sit around doing endless factory spam. I want to build tanks, ships and space cruisers and then go crush the local wildlife and conquer alien civilizations with what my factories have made. I want to build automatic rifles with high-capacity magazines and render certain undesireable local alien wildlife extinct. I even want to explore strange new worlds and colonize them with such notoriety that it makes the Klendathu Drop from Starship Troopers look like a toddler's birthday party and so I get a holiday made in my name, and centuries later that holiday gets virulently hated by some blue-haired nutcase college-age space-kids with nose rings and daddy-issues.

But nope, you can't do any of that in this game. It's just more and more factory nonsense.

Suffice to say, this game is definitely not for me.

I'm going back to Empyrion Galactic Survival.

I don't know if I had more fun with the game overall or not.
The game got my interest because you don't just have "factori" gameplay; you have exploration too.
I mostly built factories and then explored for a while.
While all what Ada had to tell and the conversation with the alien she had gave a nice mix, still, I don't feel for a positive in the end.
While the music is great and the exploration and item hunting were fun, towards the end it was just building factories without variety, which made the problem I had with building them worse than when I had to deal with it before just in short bursts.
The funkiness from the belt and pipes just exhausted me. 
I don't know if there was something I did wrong, but the belt and pipes did so often in the last moment jump and make a curve back to me on the stackable belt and pipe things that I didn't want to deal with it and made the last 2 "level" by hand-feeding machines. 
What made it so much worse was I had nothing else to do anymore but wait for the parts to be built.
So on one part I had fun with it, on the other not.
The whole building part was no fun for me; the constant funkiness of belts and pipes got on my nerves, and normally building in games is fun for me, but in this game it just made no fun for me.
And yes, I tried to build on platforms and all looking nice and all that, but I gave up on it because it always comes back to the fight with the belt and pipes.
In the end I started to build "wild" factories because it looked kind of better alone on the fact that everything looks like it's meant to be placed outside, so I rolled with it and got a bit more fun out of it. 
But in the end it was not enough for me to really end on a positive.
